value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or yielding carbon.

value.name: carbonate ooze
value.description: Ooze that consists of more than 50 percent carbonate skeletal remains. OneGeology.

value.name: carbonatite
value.description: Igneous rock composed of more than 50 percent modal carbonate minerals. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: carbonatitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "carbonatite".

value.name: chalk
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a soft compact form of calcium carbonate (CaCO3).

value.name: chalky
value.description: VARIANT. See "chalk".

value.name: chamosite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles chamosite, a generally greenish-gray or black silicate mineral of iron and aluminium.

value.name: chamositic
value.description: VARIANT. See "chamosite".

value.name: chert
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles the microcrystalline or cryptocrystalline form of quartz (SiO2).

value.name: cherty
value.description: VARIANT. See "chert".

value.name: chlorite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles chlorite, a generally green or black flaky phyllosilicate mineral.

value.name: chloritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "chlorite".

value.name: clay
value.description: Mud that consists of greater than 50 percent particles with grain size less than 0.004 mm.based on SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

value.name: claystone
value.description: Mudstone that contains no detectable silt, inferred to consist virtually entirely of clay-size particles. OneGeology.

value.name: coal
value.description: A consolidated organic sedimentary material having less than 75 percent moisture. This category includes low, medium, and high rank coals according to International Classification of In-Seam Coal (United Nations, 1998), thus including lignite. Sapropelic coal is not distinguished in this category from humic coals. Formed from the compaction or induration of variously altered plant remains similar to those of peaty deposits. Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.

value.name: concretionary
value.description: VARIANT. See "concretions".

value.name: concretions
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded masses of mineral material.

value.name: conglomerate
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded rock fragments of greater than 20mm in size.

value.name: conglomeratic
value.description: VARIANT. See "conglomerate".

value.name: coral
value.description: DEPRECATED. See "coral fragments".

value.name: coral fragments
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles corals (late Pre-Cambrian - Recent) and/or coral fragments.

value.name: coralline
value.description: VARIANT. See "coral fragments".

value.name: crinoidal
value.description: VARIANT. See "crinoids".

value.name: crinoids
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles crinoids (Mid Cambrian - Recent) and/or crinoid fragments.

value.name: dacite
value.description: Fine grained or porphyritic crystalline rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 20 and 60 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.65. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 4 and 5 or chemically in TAS Field O3. Typcially composed of quartz and sodic plagioclase with minor amounts of biotite and/or hornblende and/or pyroxene; fine-grained equivalent of granodiorite and tonalite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: dacitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "dacite".

value.name: diabase
value.description: Igneous rock of grain size intermediate between basalt and gabbro composed of plagioclase feldspar, pyroxene and opaque minerals. Synonym: dolerite.

value.name: diabasic
value.description: VARIANT. See "diabase".

value.name: diamictite
value.description: Unsorted or poorly sorted, clastic sedimentary rock with a wide range of particle sizes including a muddy matrix. Biogenic materials that have such texture are excluded. Distinguished from conglomerate, sandstone, mudstone based on polymodality and lack of structures related to transport and deposition of sediment by moving air or water. If more than 10 percent of the fine grained matrix is of indeterminant clastic or diagenetic origin and the fabric is matrix supported, may also be categorized as wacke. Fairbridge and Bourgeois 1978.

value.name: diamictitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "diamictite".

value.name: diatomaceous
value.description: VARIANT. See "diatoms".

value.name: diatoms
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles diatoms and/or diatom fragments.

value.name: diorite
value.description: Plutonic igneous rock consisting of plagioclase feldspar, commonly with hornblende and biotite.

value.name: dioritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "diorite".

value.name: dioritoid
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting of intermediate plagioclase, commonly with hornblende and often with biotite or augite. Plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater that 0.65, and anorthite content of plagioclase is less than 50 percent. Less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 (and their subdivisions). LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: dioritoidic
value.description: VARIANT. See "dioritoid".

value.name: doleritic rock
value.description: Dark colored gabbroic (basaltic) or dioritic (andesitic) rock intermediate in grain size between basalt and gabbro and composed of plagioclase, pyroxene and opaque minerals; often with ophitic texture. Typically occurs as hypabyssal intrusions. Includes dolerite, microdiorite, diabase and microgabbro. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: dolomite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling a magnesium-rich carbonate mineral of calcium (CaMg(CO3)2).

value.name: dolomite concretion
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology has rounded nodules of dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2).

value.name: dolomite stringer
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains thin beds of dolomite (CaMg(CO3)2).

value.name: dolomitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "dolomite".

value.name: eclogite
value.description: Metamorphic rock composed of 75 percent or more (by volume) omphacite and garnet, both of which are present as major constituents, the amount of neither of them being higher than 75 percent (by volume); the presence of plagioclase precludes classification as an eclogite. IUGS SCMR 2007

value.name: eclogitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "eclogite".

value.name: exotic alkaline rock
value.description: Kimberlite, lamproite, or lamprophyre. Generally are potassic, mafic or ultramafic rocks. Olivine (commonly serpentinized in kimberlite), and phlogopite are significant constituents. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: feldspar
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the rock-forming aluminosilicate minerals of sodium, potassium or calcium.

value.name: feldsparic
value.description: VARIANT. See "feldspar".

value.name: feldspathic
value.description: VARIANT. See "feldspar".

value.name: feldspathic arenite
value.description: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Sandstones that contain less than 90 percent quartz.Dott, R. H, (1964). Wacke, Graywacke and matrix-what approach to immature sandstone classification: Journal of Sedimentary Petrology, v-34, p. 625-632.

value.name: ferruginous
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling minerals rich in iron oxide or iron hydroxide.

value.name: fine grained igneous rock
value.description: Undifferentaited Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of crystals that are too small to determine mineralogy with the unaided eye; framework may include up to 50 percent glass. A significant percentage of the rock by volume may be phenocrysts. Includes rocks that are generally called volcanic rocks. Gillespie and Styles 1999; LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: fissile
value.description: DEPRECATED. The term 'fissile' doesn't belong in this list as it is neither qualifier or modifier .... it is a descriptor of 'grain fabric'.

value.name: foid dioritoid
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock in which M is less than 90, the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.5, feldspathoid minerals form 10-60 percent of the QAPF fraction, plagioclase has anorthite content less than 50 percent. These rocks typically contain large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 13 and 14. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: foid gabbroid
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock in which M is less than 90, the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is greater than 0.5, feldspathoids form 10-60 percent of the QAPF fraction, and plagioclase has anorthite content greater than 50 percent. These rocks typically contain large amounts of mafic minerals. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 13 and 14. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: foid syenitoid
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, contains between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes QAPF fields 11 and 12. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: foidite
value.description: Foiditoid that contains greater than 90 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: foiditic
value.description: VARIANT. See "foidite".

value.name: foiditoid
value.description: Fine grained crystalline rock containing less than 90 percent mafic minerals and more than 60 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15 or chemically in TAS field F. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: foidolite
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline rock containing more than 60 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 15. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: foidolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "foidolite".

value.name: foliated metamorphic rock
value.description: Metamorphic rock in which 10 percent or more of the contained mineral grains are elements in a planar or linear fabric. Cataclastic or glassy character precludes classification with this concept. Based on NADM SLTT metamorphic.

value.name: foraminifera
value.description: VARIANT. See "forams".

value.name: foraminiferous
value.description: VARIANT. See "forams".

value.name: forams
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains marine micro-organisms of the order Foraminifera (Devonian - Recent), having a calcareous shell.

value.name: forams undifferentiated
value.description: DEPRECATED. See forams.

value.name: fossil fragment
value.description: DEPRECATED. See "fossil fragments".

value.name: fossil fragments
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains material comprised of fossils or fossil fragments.

value.name: fossiliferous
value.description: VARIANT. See "fossil fragments".

value.name: fossils undifferentiated
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains material comprised of fossils or fossil fragments of undetermined type type, form or species.

value.name: fragmental igneous rock
value.description: Igneous rock in which greater than 75 percent of the rock consists of fragments produced as a result of igneous rock-forming process. Includes pyroclastic rocks, autobreccia associated with lava flows and intrusive breccias. Excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes (see Tuffite).

value.name: gabbro
value.description: Gabbroic rock that contains between 0 and 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 10 as gabbro. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: gabbroic
value.description: VARIANT. See "gabbro".

value.name: gabbroic rock
value.description: Gabbroid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9 in the QAPF fraction. Includes QAPF fields 10*, 10, and 10'. This category includes the various categories defined in LeMaitre et al. (2002) based on the mafic mineralogy, but apparently not subdivided based on the quartz/feldspathoid content. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: gabbroid
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, and up to 20 percent quartz or up to 10 percent feldspathoid in the QAPF fraction. The ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.65, and anorthite content of the plagioclase is greater than 50 percent. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 9 and 10 and their subdivisions. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: gabbroidic
value.description: VARIANT. See "gabbroid".

value.name: gilsonite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains material containing or resembling gilsonite (uintaite), a brilliant black variety of asphalt occurring in rounded masses.

value.name: gilsonitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "gilsonite".

value.name: glauconite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the generally greenish authogenic clay mineral glauconite.

value.name: glauconitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "glauconite".

value.name: gneiss
value.description: Foliated metamorphic rock with bands or lenticles rich in granular minerals alternating with bands or lenticles rich in minerals with a flaky or elongate prismatic habit. Mylonitic foliation or well developed, continuous schistosity (greater than 50 percent of the rock consists of grains participate in a planar or linear fabric) precludes classification with this concept. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

value.name: gneissic
value.description: VARIANT. See "gneiss".

value.name: granite
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting of quartz, alkali feldspar and plagioclase (typically sodic) in variable amounts, usually with biotite and/or hornblende. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 3. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: granitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "granite".

value.name: granodiorite
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline rock consisting essentially of quartz, sodic plagioclase and lesser amounts of alkali feldspar with minor hornblende and biotite. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 4. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: granodioritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "granodiorite".

value.name: granofels
value.description: Metamorphic rock with granoblastic fabric and very little or no foliation (less than 10 percent of the mineral grains in the rock are elements in a planar or linear fabric). Grainsize not specified. SLTTm 2004.

value.name: granulite
value.description: Metamorphic rock of high metamorphic grade in which Fe-Mg silicate minerals are dominantly hydroxl-free; feldspar must be present, and muscovite is absent; rock contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 75 percent calcite and/or dolomite, less than 75 percent quartz, less than 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), and less than 50 percent calc-silicate minerals. Fettes and Desmons (2007). See also Wimmenauer (1985), Winkler (1979) (D.R. Bowes (1989), The Encyclopedia of Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology; Van Nostrand Reinhold ISBN: 0-442-20623-2

value.name: granulitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "granulite".

value.name: gravel
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains particles in the size range of 2mm - 20mm.

value.name: gravelly
value.description: VARIANT. See "gravel".

value.name: greenstone
value.description: Chlorite actinolite epidote metamorphic rocks. Metamorphic rock characterized by 50 percent or more of combined chlorite, actinolite and epidote. Category for rocks generally named greenschist or greenstone. OneGeology, simplified for WITSML to Greenstone.

value.name: gumbo
value.description: A term used in the U.S. for clay soils that become sticky, impervious, and plastic when wet.

value.name: gypsiferous
value.description: VARIANT. See "gypsum".

value.name: gypsum
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the evaporite mineral gypsum (CaSO4.2H2O).

value.name: halite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or resembles the common evaporite mineral Halite (NaCl).

value.name: halitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "halite".

value.name: hornfels
value.description: Granofels formed by contact metamorphism, composed of a mosaic of equidimensional grains in a characteristically granoblastic or decussate matrix; porphyroblasts or relict phenocrysts may be present. Typically fine grained.

value.name: hornfelsic
value.description: VARIANT. See "hornfels".

value.name: igneous
value.description: VARIANT. See "igneous rock".

value.name: igneous rock
value.description: Undefined rock formed as a result of igneous processes, for example intrusion and cooling of magma in the crust, or volcanic eruption. Neuendorf et al 2005.

value.name: illite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the common clay mineral illite.

value.name: illitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "illite".

value.name: impact generated material
value.description: Material that contains features indicative of shock metamorphism, such as microscopic planar deformation features within grains or shatter cones, interpreted to be the result of extraterrestrial bolide impact. Includes breccias and melt rocks. StÃ¶ffler and Grieve 2007; Jackson 1997.

value.name: impure dolomite
value.description: Impure carbonate sedimentary rock with a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

value.name: impure limestone
value.description: Impure carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. OneGeology.

value.name: intrusive rock (plutonic)
value.description: Igneous rock formed by cooling and solidification of magma within the earth's crust.

value.name: iron rich sedimentary rock
value.description: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent iron-bearing minerals (hematite, magnetite, limonite-group, siderite, iron-sulfides), as determined by hand-lens or petrographic analysis. Corresponds to a rock typically containing 15 percent iron by weight. Hallsworth and Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004.

value.name: kalsilitic and melilitic rocks
value.description: Igneous rock containing greater than 10 percent melilite or kalsilite. Typically undersaturated, ultrapotassic (kalsilitic rocks) or calcium-rich (melilitic rocks) mafic or ultramafic rocks. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: kaolinite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling the common clay mineral kaolinite.

value.name: kaolinitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "kaolinite".

value.name: komatiitic rock
value.description: Ultramafic, magnesium-rich volcanic rock, typically with spinifex texture of intergrown skeletal and bladed olivine and pyroxene crystals set in abundant glass. Includes komatiite and meimechite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: latitic rock
value.description: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.35 and 0.65. QAPF fields 8, 8' and 8*. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: lignite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a soft brownish-black form of coal.

value.name: lignitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "lignite".

value.name: lime boundstone
value.description: Biogenic textural class. The origianl components were bound and encrusted together by the action of plants and animals in the position of growth. That is, Reef limestones. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

value.name: lime framestone
value.description: Biogenic textural class. Carbonate reef rock consisting of a rigid framework of colonies, shells or skeletons, with internal cavities filled with fine sediment; usually created through the activities of colonial organisms. Source () Hallsworth & Knox 1999; SLTTs 2004, Table 15-3-1

value.name: lime grainstone
value.description: Depositional textural cassification. Grain supported carbonate with little ( less than 25 percent) carbonate matrix. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

value.name: lime mudstone
value.description: Depositional textural cassification. Original components not bound together during deposition. Contains mud (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Mud-supported (particles greater than 20 mm). Less than 10 percent Grains. Mudstone that contains between 10 and 50 percent carbonate minerals in the mud size fraction. Carbonate origin is not specified. The operational test typically used to identify this category is if the rock fizzes when hydrochloric acid is applied. The '10 percent carbonate' criteria is a fuzzy boundary.

value.name: lime packstone
value.description: Grain supported carbonate. Original components not bound together during deposition. Contains mud (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

value.name: lime wackestone
value.description: Depositional textural cassification. Original components not bound together during deposition. Matrix supported. Contains less than 75 percent mud grade (less than 32 micrometer) calcite. (clay and fine silt-size carbonate). Mud-supported (particles greater than 20 mm). Greater than 10 percent Grains. Hallsworth and Knox 1999. These are incremental additions to OneGeology to add the Dunham depositional terms used in Carbonates. When plotting these, they will all plot as Limestone.

value.name: limestone
value.description: Pure carbonate sedimentary rock with a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1. Includes limestone and dolomitic limestone. OneGeology.

value.name: limestone stringer
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains thin beds of limestone.

value.name: limestone, argillaceous
value.description: A limestone homogeneously mixed with 10-50% clay minerals.

value.name: limestone, dolomitic
value.description: A limestone containing 10-50% dolomite and 50-90% calcite.

value.name: limestone, sandy
value.description: A limestone homogeneously mixed with 10-50% quartz grains.

value.name: lithic
value.description: VARIANT. See "lithic fragments".

value.name: lithic fragment
value.description: DEPRECATED. See "lithic fragments".

value.name: lithic fragments
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of undetermined rock fragments.

value.name: marble
value.description: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than 75 percent fine- to coarse-grained recrystallized calcite and/or dolomite; usually with a granoblastic, saccharoidal texture. IUGS SCMR 2007

value.name: marcasite
value.description: Indicates that the associate lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of the white (gem) form of iron pyrites (FeS).

value.name: marcasitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "marcasite".

value.name: marl
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of a crumbly mixture of clays, calcium and magnesium carbonates.

value.name: marly
value.description: VARIANT. See "marl".

value.name: metamorphic rock
value.description: Undefined rock formed by solid-state mineralogical, chemical and/or structural changes to a pre-existing rock, in response to marked changes in temperature, pressure, shearing stress and chemical environment. Not further defined. Jackson 1997.

value.name: mica
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of mica, a group of hydrous aluminosilicate minerals that split easily into thin partly-transparent sheets.

value.name: mica schist
value.description: A schist that consists of more than 50 percent mica minerals, typically muscovite or biotite. Special type included to distinguish this common variety of schist. OneGeology.

value.name: micaceous
value.description: VARIANT. See "mica".

value.name: microfossil
value.description: DEPRECATED. See microfossils.

value.name: microfossiliferous
value.description: VARIANT. See "microfossils".

value.name: microfossils
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains undifferentiated microscopic fossils.

value.name: migmatite
value.description: Silicate metamorphic rock that is pervasively heterogeneous on a decimeter to meter scale that typically consists of darker and lighter parts; the darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks whereas the lighter parts are of igneous-looking appearance. Fette and Desmons (2007)

value.name: migmatitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "migmatite".

value.name: monzogabbro
value.description: Monzogabbroic rock that contains between 0 an 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: monzogabbroic
value.description: VARIANT. See "monzogabbro".

value.name: mud
value.description: Clastic sediment consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud-size to sand-size particle ratio greater than 1. More than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin. Definition of mud from SLTTs 2004 muddy sediment; particle sizes defined from Krumbein phi scale (W C Krumbein & L L Sloss, Stratigraphy and Sedimentation, 2nd edition, Freeman, San Francisco, 1963; Krumbein and Pettijohn, 1938, Manual of Sedimentary Petrography: New York, Appleton Century Co., Inc.).

value.name: muddy
value.description: VARIANT. See "mud".

value.name: mudstone
value.description: Clastic sedimentary rock consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud to sand ratio greater than 1. The definition includes Claystone, Siltstone and Shale. Pettijohn et al. 1987 referenced in Hallsworth & Knox 1999; extrapolated from Folk, 1954, Figure 1a.

value.name: mylonitic rock
value.description: Metamorphic rock characterised by a foliation resulting from tectonic grain size reduction, in which more than 10 percent of the rock volume has undergone grain size reduction. Includes protomylonite, mylonite, ultramylonite, and blastomylonite. Marshak & Mitra 1988.

value.name: no description
value.description: DEPRECATED. Where's the validity of creating a null entry for either qualifier or modifer?.

value.name: no sample
value.description: A sample would be expected, given the drilling situation, but nothing was seen at the shakers, implying either solution in the mud system of a salt, or lack of returns. WITSML.

value.name: none
value.description: DEPRECATED. Where's the validity of creating a null entry for either qualifier or modifer?.

value.name: oncolite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology is largely composed of oncoliths (oncoids).

value.name: oncolith
value.description: DEPRECATED. See oncoliths.

value.name: oncolithic
value.description: DEPRECATED. See oncoliths.

value.name: oncoliths
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of oncoliths (oncoids), a type of carbonate-coated grain with irregular laminae.

value.name: oncolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "oncoliths".

value.name: ooid or oolith
value.description: DEPRECATED. See ooids.

value.name: ooids
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or characteristic of ooids (ooliths), small round grains consisting of calcium carbonate, silica, or dolomite.

value.name: ooliths
value.description: VARIANT. See "ooids".

value.name: oolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "ooids".

value.name: ooze
value.description: Biogenic sediment consisting of less than 1 percent gravel-size (greater than or equal to 2 mm) particles, with a sand to mud ratio less than 1 to 9, and less than 50 percent carbonate minerals. Based on Bates and Jackson 1987 & Hallsworth & Knox 1999.

value.name: ophiolite
value.description: Basic and ultra-basic igneous rocks and their metamorposed, often hydrated, derivatives, believed to represent former oceanic crust.

value.name: ophiolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "ophiolite".

value.name: organic bearing mudstone
value.description: Mudstone that contains a significant amount of organic carbon, typically kerogen. Commonly finely laminated, brown or black in color. Neuendorf et al. 2005;

value.name: ostracodal
value.description: VARIANT. See "ostracods".

value.name: ostracods
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling ostracod (Cambrian - Recent) fossils.

value.name: peat
value.description: Unconsolidated organic-rich sediment composed of at least 50 percent semi-carbonised plant remains; individual remains commonly seen with unaided eye; yellowish brown to brownish black; generally fibrous texture; can be plastic or friable. In its natural state it can be readily cut and has a very high moisture content, generally greater than 90 percent. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is less than one (Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.). Hallsworth & Knox 1999.

value.name: peaty
value.description: VARIANT. See "peat".

value.name: pebble
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded rock fragments in the size range of 2mm - 64mm.

value.name: pebbly
value.description: VARIANT. See "pebble".

value.name: pegmatite
value.description: Exceptionally coarse grained crystalline rock with interlocking crystals; most grains are 1 centimeter or more diameter; composition is generally that of granite, but the term may refer to the coarse grained facies of any type of igneous rock; usually found as irregular dikes, lenses, or veins associated with plutons or batholiths. Neuendorf et al 2005.

value.name: pegmatitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "pegmatite".

value.name: pellet
value.description: DEPRECATED. See pellets.

value.name: pelletal
value.description: VARIANT. See "pellets".

value.name: pellets
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of small ovoid or spherical particles of microcrystalline calcite, in the size range 0.03mm - 0.15mm.

value.name: peloid
value.description: DEPRECATED. See peloids.

value.name: peloidal
value.description: VARIANT. See "peloids".

value.name: peloids
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of sand-size grains of carbonate mud.

value.name: peridotite
value.description: Ultramafic rock consisting of more than 40 percent (by volume) olivine with pyroxene and/or amphibole and little or no feldspar. Commonly altered to serpentinite. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as dunite, harzburgite, lherzolite, wehrlite, olivinite, pyroxene peridotite, pyroxene hornblende peridotite or hornblende peridotite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: peridotitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "peridotite".

value.name: phaneritic igneous rock
value.description: Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of individual crystals that can be discerned with the unaided eye. Bounding grain size is on the order of 32 to 100 microns. Igneous rocks with 'exotic' composition are excluded from this concept. Neuendorf et al 2005.

value.name: phonolite
value.description: Phonolitoid in which the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is less than 0.1. Rock consists of alkali feldspar, feldspathoid minerals, and mafic minerals. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: phonolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "phonolite".

value.name: phonolitoid
value.description: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 11 and 12, and TAS field Ph. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: phosphate
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains phosphates.

value.name: phosphate rock
value.description: Any rock containing phosphate minerals such as apatite of sufficient purity and abundance to be an economic resource.

value.name: phosphatic
value.description: VARIANT. See "phosphate".

value.name: phyllite
value.description: Rock with a well developed, continuous schistosity, an average grain size between 0.1 and 0.5 millimeters, and a silvery sheen on cleavage surfaces. Individual phyllosilicate grains are barely visible with the unaided eye. IUGS SCMR 2007.

value.name: phyllitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "phyllite".

value.name: pisolite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology is composed largely of pisoliths (pisoids).

value.name: pisolith
value.description: DEPRECATED. See pisoliths.

value.name: pisoliths
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains or is characteristic of sub-spherical usually carbonate coated grains, of diameter greater than 2mm.

value.name: pisolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "pisolite".

value.name: plant remains
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains remains of a probable botanical origin.

value.name: porphyritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "porphyry".

value.name: porphyry
value.description: Igneous rock that contains conspicuous phenocrysts in a finer grained groundmass; groundmass itself may be phaneritic or fine-grained. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: potassium and magnesium salts
value.description: Evaporite composed with significant (greater than 50 percent) magnesium salts, such as Carnallite /Kainite/Polyhalite/Kieserite/Bischofite/Tachydrite. WITSML.

value.name: pyrite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling the sulphide mineral of iron (FeS2).

value.name: pyritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "pyrite".

value.name: pyroclastic breccia
pyroclastic rock
value.description: Fragmental igneous rock that consists of greater than 75 percent fragments produced as a direct result of eruption or extrusion of magma from within the earth onto its surface. Includes autobreccia associated with lava flows and excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes. Based on LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: pyroxenite
value.description: Ultramafic phaneritic igneous rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as olivine pyroxenite, olivine-hornblende pyroxenite, pyroxenite, orthopyroxenite, clinopyroxenite and websterite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: pyroxenitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "pyroxenite".

value.name: quartiferous
value.description: VARIANT. See "quartz".

value.name: quartz
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (crystalline) material containing or resembling the common silica mineral quartz (SiO2).

value.name: quartz arenite
value.description: Clastic sandstone that contains less than 10 percent matrix. Matrix is mud-size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products) of detrital or diagenetic nature. Sandstones that contain more than 90 percent of siliceous grains. Grains can include quartz or chert rock fragments. Dott, R. H, (1964). Wacke, Graywacke and matrix-what approach to immature sandstone classification: Journal of Sedimentary Petrology, v-34, p. 625-632.

value.name: quartzite
value.description: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than or equal to 75 percent quartz; typically granoblastic texture. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

value.name: quartzitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "quartzite".

value.name: radiolaria
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling fossils of the marine protozoan order of Radiolaria (Cambrian - Recent), generally with endoskeletons of opaline silica.

value.name: radiolarian
value.description: VARIANT. See "radiolaria".

value.name: rhyolite
value.description: rhyolitoid in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is between 0.1 and 0.65. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: rhyolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "rhyolite".

value.name: rock salt
value.description: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent halite. Superset of Halite, Silvite and Potassium and magnesium salts. OneGeology.

value.name: rootlets
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling plant roots, or structures (rhizoliths) resulting from the mineralization of plant roots by accumulation/cementation or replacement.

value.name: salty
value.description: VARIANT. See "rock salt".

value.name: sand
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (crystalline) material containing or resembling mineral or rock grains of diameter in the range of 0.625mm - 2mm.

value.name: sandstone
value.description: Clastic sedimentary rock in which less than 30 percent of particles are greater than 2 millimeter in diameter (gravel) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005; particle size from Wentworth grade scale.

value.name: sandy
value.description: VARIANT. See "sand".

value.name: sapropel
value.description: Jelly like organic rich sediment composed of plant remains, usually algal. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is greater than one (Economic Commission for Europe, Committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.). Neuendorf et al. 2005.

value.name: sapropelic
value.description: VARIANT. See "sapropel".

value.name: schist
value.description: Foliated phaneritic metamorphic rock with well developed, continuous schistosity, meaning that greater than 50 percent of the rock by volume is mineral grains with a thin tabular, lamellar, or acicular prismatic crystallographic habit that are oriented in a continuous planar or linear fabric. SLTTm 2004; Neuendorf et al. 2005.

value.name: schisty
value.description: VARIANT. See "schist".

value.name: sepentinitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "serpentinite".

value.name: serpentinite
value.description: Rock consisting of more than 75 percent serpentine-group minerals, eg. antigorite, chrysotile or lizardite; accessory chlorite, talc and magnetite may be present; derived from hydration of ferromagnesian silicate minerals such as olivine and pyroxene. Neuendorf et al. 2005.

value.name: shale
value.description: Laminated mudstone that will part or break along thin, closely spaced layers parallel to stratification. NADM SLTT sedimentary, 2004. WITSML note: Since Hallsworth and Knox did not recognise the term Shale, some operators do not use this in descriptions, but do plot it graphically.

value.name: shaly
value.description: VARIANT. See "shale".

value.name: shell
value.description: DEPRECATED. See "shell fragments".

value.name: shell fragments
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling shells (generally bivalves) or fragments thereof.

value.name: shelly
value.description: VARIANT. See "shell fragments".

value.name: siderite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling siderite (spathic iron), a carbonate mineral of iron (FeCO3).

value.name: siderite concretion
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology contains rounded masses comprised of the mineral siderite (spathic iron), a carbonate mineral of iron (FeCO3).

value.name: sideritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "siderite".

value.name: siliceous ooze
value.description: Ooze that consists of more than 50 percent siliceous skeletal remains. OneGeology.

value.name: silt
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material of very fine particles intermediate in size between clay and sand (0.0625mm - 2mm).

value.name: siltstone
value.description: Mudstone that contains detectable silt. OneGeology.

value.name: silty
value.description: VARIANT. See "silt".

value.name: skarn
value.description: Metasomatic rock consisting mainly of Ca-, Mg-, Fe-, or Mn-silicate minerals, which are free from or poor in water. Typically formed at the contact between a silicate rock or magma and a carbonate rock.Fettes and Desmons, 2007, p195.

value.name: skarny
value.description: VARIANT. See "skarn".

value.name: slate
value.description: Compact, fine grained rock with an average grain size less than 0.032 millimeter and a well developed schistosity (slaty cleavage), and hence can be split into slabs or thin plates. NADM metamorphic rock vocabulary SLTTm1.0; Neuendorf et al. 2005.

value.name: slaty
value.description: VARIANT. See "slate".

value.name: smectite
value.description: A matrix cement dominantly composed of Smectite. Chemically Smectite is a hydrated sodium calcium aluminium magnesium silicate hydroxide (Na,Ca)0.33(Al,Mg)2(Si4O10)(OH)2Â·nH2O. It will respond to changes in hydration, so may be altered in cuttings samples.

value.name: smectitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "smectite".

value.name: spicular
value.description: VARIANT. See "spicules".

value.name: spicule
value.description: DEPRECATED. See spicules.

value.name: spicules
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling minute needle-like structures of silica or carbonate, such as that supporting the soft tissue of certain invertebrates, especially sponges.

value.name: spilite
value.description: Altered basic to intermediate composition fine-grained igneous rock in which the feldspar is partially or completely composed of of albite, typically accompanied by chlorite, calcite, quartz, epidote, prehnite, and low-temperature hydrous crystallization products. Preservation of eruptive volcanic features is typical. Fettes and Desmon, 2007; Best, M.G., 1982, Igneous and metamorphic petrology: New York, W.H. Freeman and Company, p. 398; Neuendorf et al. 2005, p. 619.

value.name: spilitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "spilite".

value.name: stylolite
value.description: DEPRECATED. See stylolites.

value.name: stylolites
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a contact zone surface between two adjacent calcareous rocks, along which dissolution by pressure solution has ocurred and appearing in cross section as a series of jagged interlocking up-and-down projections (of insoluble clay minerals) that resemble a suture.

value.name: stylolitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "stylolites".

value.name: syenite
value.description: Plutonic igneous rock composed essentially of alkali feldspar, with lesser sodic plagioclase, biotite and hornblende, and minor quartz.

value.name: syenitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "syenite".

value.name: syenitoid
value.description: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting mainly of alkali feldspar and plagioclase; minor quartz or nepheline may be present, along with pyroxene, amphibole or biotite. Ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is less than 0.65, quartz forms less than 20 percent of QAPF fraction, and feldspathoid minerals form less than 10 percent of QAPF fraction. Includes rocks classified in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 and their subdivisions. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: sylvite
value.description: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent Sylvite (KCL). OneGeology.

value.name: sylvitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "sylvite".

value.name: tarry
value.description: VARIANT. See "bitumen".

value.name: tephrite
value.description: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9, and contains less than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: tephritic
value.description: VARIANT. See "tephrite".

value.name: tephritoid
value.description: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.5. Includes rocks classified in QAPF field 13 and 14 or chemically in TAS field U1 as basanite or tephrite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: tholeiitic basalt
value.description: Tholeiitic basalt is defined here to contain 2 pyroxene phases and interstitial quartz or tridymite or cristobalite in the groundmass. Pyroxene (augite and orthopyroxene or pigeonite) and calcium-rich plagioclase are common phenocryst minerals. Olivine may also be a phenocryst, and when present, may have rims of pigeonite. Only in tholeiitic basalt is olivine in reaction relationship with melt. Interstitial siliceous residue may be present, and is often glassy. Tholeiitic basalt is relatively poor in sodium. This category includes most basalts of the ocean floor, most large oceanic islands, and continental flood basalts such as the Columbia River Plateau.Carmichael, I.S. Turner, F.J., Verhoogen, John, 1974, Igneous petrology: New York, McGraw HIll Book Co., p.42-43.

value.name: tonalite
value.description: Granitoid consisting of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 5; ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.9. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: tonalitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "tonalite".

value.name: trachyte
value.description: A group of fine-grained often porphyritic volcanic rocks containing alkali feldspar and minor mafic minerals.

value.name: trachytic
value.description: VARIANT. See "trachyte".

value.name: trachytic rock
value.description: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.35. QAPF fields 7, 7', and 7*. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: trachytoid
value.description: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.65. Mafic minerals typically include amphibole or mica; typically porphyritic. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 (with subdivisions) or chemically in TAS Field T as trachyte or latite. LeMaitre et al. 2002.

value.name: travertine
value.description: Biotically or abiotically precipitated calcium carbonate, from spring-fed, heated, or ambient-temperature water. May be white and spongy, various shades of orange, tan or gray, and ranges to dense, banded or laminated rock. Macrophytes, bryophytes, algae, cyanobacteria and other organisms often colonize the surface of travertine and may be preserved, to produce the porous varieties. Neuendorf et al. 2005; Chafetz, H.S., and Folk, R.L., 1984, Travertine: Depositional morphology an dthe bacterially constructed constituents: J. Sed. Petrology, v. 126, p.57-74.

value.name: tuff
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises (matrix) material containing or resembling pyroclastic detrital material (volcanic ash).

value.name: tuffaceous
value.description: VARIANT. See "tuff".

value.name: tuffite
value.description: Indicates that the associated lithology comprises material containing or resembling a fine grained matrix of volcanic breccia with intruded grains of fluidized sediment.

value.name: tuffitic
value.description: VARIANT. See "tuffite".

value.name: ultrabasic
value.description: A class of igneous rocks composed mostly of mafic minerals such as pyroxenes along with calcic feldspar, with no free silica and a total silica content less than about 45%.

value.name: undifferentiated
value.description: The lithology is not differentiated. This is typically used to fill out a lithology description to 100 percent.

value.name: wacke
value.description: Clastic sandstone with more than 10 percent matrix of indeterminate detrital or diagenetic nature. Matrix is mud size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products). Pettijohn, Potter, Siever, 1972, Sand and Sandstone: New York, Springer Verlag, 681 p.

value.name: unknown
value.description: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

enumList.name: TrajStnCalcAlgorithm
enumList.description: The type of algorithm used in the calculation of a trajectory station dependent data. This is traditionally positional information except for the cases of inertial survey data. See API Bulletin D20 "BULLETIN ON DIRECTIONAL DRILLING SURVEY CALCULATION METHODS AND TERMINOLOGY", First Edition December 31, 1985.

value.name: constant tool face
value.description: An algorithm used to design a well trajectory during the planning stage

value.name: minimum curvature
value.description: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is that of a circular arc in 3-D space. Also known as "Minimum Radius Of Curvature" method.

value.name: tangential
value.description: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is a straight line oriented according to the seconds stations orientation. Also known as "Backward Station" and "Terminal Angle" methods.

value.name: balanced tangential
value.description: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is along two straight lines, with the first section oriented according to the first stations orientation and the second line oriented according to the second stations orientation. Each line segment is set to have a length of half the measured depth difference between the two stations. Also known as "Acceleration", "Secant", "Trapezoidal", and "Vector Averaging" methods.

value.name: average angle
value.description: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path between stations is along a straight line oriented according to the average of the inclination and azimuth orientations of the start and end stations. Also known as "Angle Averaging" method.

value.name: radius of curvature
value.description: An algorithm used to calculate the well trajectory spatial position (X,Y,Z) at execution stage or planning stage. The assumed path is a helix with a fixed vertical radius wrapped around a cylinder of fixed radius. Both radii can tend to infinity yielding simple circular arcs in either the horizontal or vertical planes.

value.name: inertial
value.description: This encompasses surveying methods where the positional data was not derived from a transformation of MD,INC,AZM, but are provided directly by some other mechanism such as direct positional output from an inertial gyro system.

value.name: custom
value.description: This encompasses methodologies which are similar to the Inertial method in that they are direct populations of the positional data, which have been determined by some other possibly non-published methodology.

value.name: unknown
value.description: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.

enumList.name: TypeSurveyTool
enumList.description: Type of directional survey tool; a very generic classification.

value.name: magnetic MWD
value.description: A tool measuring downhole inclination and azimuth from sets of accelerometers and magnetometers sensors.

value.name: magnetic multiple-shot
value.description: A tool measuring downhole inclination and azimuth from photo-mechanical inclinometers and magnetic compass.

value.name: unknown
value.description: The value is not known. This value should not be used in normal situations. All reasonable attempts should be made to determine the appropriate value. Use of this value may result in rejection in some situations.
